citeinfo.origin: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), Southwest Fisheries Science Center (SFSC), Pacific Fisheries Environmental Laboratory (PFEL)
citeinfo.title: FNMOC 181x360 Six-Hourly 10-m Wind Field

descript.abstract:
10-m six-hourly means of surface winds computed from the Fleet Numerical Meteorology and Oceanography Center (FNMOC ) (http://www.fnmoc.navy.mil) on a 360 by 181 global spherical grid (1 degree). The variables are as follows: 1.Zonal Component of surface wind 2.Meridional Component of surface wind 3.Surface Wind Vector and Magnitude 4.Zonal Component of surface wind stress 5.Meridional Component of surface wind stress 6.Surface Wind Stress Vector and Curl
Method: Wind speed and stress are computed for each 6 hour field before averaging. Note: Vector winds and wind stress are plotted on top of scalar wind magnitude and wind stress curl, however data file downloads will only yield wind magnitude and wind stress curl. To obtain vector quantities of wind speed and stress, you must download the zonal and meridional components separately.
Download or plot the data from the PFEL Live Access Server (LAS) (http://www.pfeg.noaa.gov/products/las.html)
For more information on the models used to compute these data see: ﾷRosmond, T. E., 1992: A prototype fully coupled Ocean-Atmosphere Prediction System, Oceanography Vol. 5, No. 1, 25-30. ﾷClancy, R. M., 1992: Operational Modeling: Ocean Modeling at the Fleet Numberical Oceanography Center, Oceanography Vol. 5, No. 1, 31-35.
[ Reference: PICES Scientific Report No. 18 2001, Proceedings of the PICES/CoML/IPRC Workshop on "Impact of Climate Variability on Observation and Prediction of Ecosystem and Biodiversity Changes in the North Pacific", http://www.pices.int/publications/scientific_reports/Report18/default.aspx. ]
descript.purpose: To provide model derived data products which will assist in describing the variability in the ocean environment.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system. NOAA makes no warranty, expressed or implied, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty.
